Relapses are the rule => systematically suggest quitting

*Craving and withdrawal syndrome are factors in relapse.
*Alcohol and cannabis use are factors in relapse.

The quality and frequency of follow-up improve the chances of successful weaning.

* The frequency should be agreed with the smoker (6 to 12 months).
* A "successful" withdrawal is one that lasts ≥ 1 year.
* Regular follow-up helps prevent relapses.

Relapse must be played down (often a necessary stage in learning to live without tobacco).

* reward the efforts made
* analyse the circumstances of the relapse
* maintaining follow-up with a view to a new attempt.

question.title: What is a key aspect of long-term management of smoking addiction?
question.description: According to the provided text, what is a crucial factor in the success of quitting smoking?

option_a.title: Rewarding the smoker for small milestones
option_a.description: This approach may help motivate the smoker to continue their efforts.

option_b.title: Analyzing the circumstances of the relapse
option_b.description: This approach may help the smoker understand what triggered their relapse and prevent future ones.

option_c.title: Maintaining regular follow-up with a view to a new attempt
option_c.description: This approach may help the smoker stay on track and eventually quit for good.

option_d.title: Rewarding the efforts made and analyzing the circumstances of the relapse
option_d.description: This approach may help the smoker stay motivated and understand what triggered their relapse.

correct_option.title: Maintaining regular follow-up with a view to a new attempt
correct_option.description: This is the correct answer, as regular follow-up is crucial for preventing relapses.
